reviewText: This is a very fun dvd for "B" movie fans! British Intelligence revolves around WWI and a time of spies. Karloff fans will have fun with his portrayal of a butler who may be a German or British spy. Valder (Karloff) works for a member of the British Cabinet, where a secret meeting is taking place. Looming over the meeting are bombs being dropped over London and the possibility of a deadly and souless spy wrecking havoc on British soil. Margaret Lindsay is an English nurse who may also be a spy. It is no great shakes, but fun to watch if you are in the right mood, or a Karloff fan.The real fun here, however, is the three Bulldog Drummond "B" entries! H. C. "Snapper" McNeil's Bulldog Drummond stories can be traced on film all the way back to the silent era. While the two films with Ronald Colman are considered to be the best by many critics, the most fun and entertaining are surely derived from the "B" films with John Howard in the role of Hugh Drummond. Others had their turn, however, and in Bulldog Drummond Escapes, a young and dashing Ray Milland acquits himself quite nicely. The series had cute Heather Angel as Hugh's fun bride-to-be, Phyllis Clavering, in most entries. Louise Campbell was good in the others, but Heather was missed by fans. E.E. Clive was great as Bulldog's valet, Tenny, and Reginald Denny offered moments of amusement as his affable pal, Algy. H.B. Warner was fun as Colonel Nielson and Elizabeth Patterson swell as Phyllis' Aunt Blanche, always skeptical that Bulldog would ever make it to the alter with Phyllis.While Bulldog Drummond's Peril isn't the sharpest film in the series, it is an okay entry with Howard chasing after his wedding gift, getting sidetracked once again from the alter, and Phyllis. Ray Milland has fun as Bulldog in Bulldog Drummond Escapes. This one is a lighthearted entry. Pal Algy is an expecting father as Bulldog arrives by plane with a bit of derring-do, landing in a dangerous fog. Guy Standing is the Clolonel this time, and he's not pleased to see Hugh, knowing his arrival is sure to bring adventure.It isn't long before his fears are realized, when our hero Bulldog finds a damsel in distress in the road. There's a murdered man nearby and the damsel disappears! Hugh suspects she's being held against her will in Greystone Manor, but can't convince the Colonel. Pretty Heather Angel is enough to make any man take a risk or two, and Bulldog's nose for adventure and damsels lead him right to danger.Milland makes a fun and dashing Drummond in this entry in the series. This one is important because it shows how Bulldog and Phyllis first met. The very fun tone makes for fine entertainment for "B" fans. Bulldog plays a clever trick to tear Algy away from the delivery and an even neater trick involving a dummy to find the evidence he needs to save Phyllis from the ruffians!Bulldog Drummond Comes Back is a terrific entry in the Bulldog Drummond "B" series, regular John Howard returning in the role of Hugh Drummond. It moves quickly and has more atmosphere than usual. Reginald Denny and E.E. Clive also return as Bulldog's pals, but Heather Angel is missed as his soon-to-be bride. Louise Campbell does a nice job as Phyllis, however, and John Barrymore's presence as the Colonel adds a serious touch to the proceedings.Phyllis is kidnapped from Rockingham by two seriously twisted criminal minds Colonel Nielson has been aware of for some time. J. Carroll Naish and Helen Freeman are fun as the evil Valdein and Irena. Nielson allows Bulldog to search for Phyllis in his own way by following the deliberate clues left him, such as phonograph records, to find his lady love.But while Bulldog and his pals go down to the docks in a merry yet somber chase, the Colonel isn't far behind. Barrymore gets to don disguises so he can follow the action without being seen. Howard, sometimes accused of being a bit bland as Drummond by some, seems a bit more dashing here opposite the Great Profile.It is Tenny (E.E. Clive) who comes to the rescue in this one in Edward T. Lowe's screenplay based on "Bulldog Drummond and the Female of the Species" by H.C. "Sapper" McNeile. Louis King directs this entry in the series with some flair and the ending is a real bang! Bulldog may have a clear path to the alter finally but for a last second breeze! A very good entry despite the absence of Heather Angel, and one Bulldog Drummond fans will enjoy.This is a very fun set of "B" films fans won't want to pass up.

reviewText: Mystery Classics are usually movies from the 30s and 40s. They've been improved, but occasionally a flaw will show itself. I like the old movies because they are well acted, don't depend on CGI to build the story, and blood is almost non-existant in most of the films. Most of the films are easy to watch and allow the viewer to let their imaginations out for some exercise. These films are good for the entire family. They don't contain bad language, adult scenes, or gratuitous violence. Actually, most of the violence takes place off stage or in shadow. I can recommend all the Mystery Classics collections since I have most of them.

reviewText: - the Commissioner of Scotland Yard (to a rather chagrined Bulldog Drummond): "Oh, don't take it so hardly. After all, you've been useful in your own quiet, acrobatic way."No one will ever inhabit the role of Bulldog Drummond quite as elegantly or with such panache as did Ronald Colman, but the gents who followed him aren't exactly piles of crap, either, as witnessed in these Bulldog Drummond entries. MYSTERY CLASSICS Volume 2 offers up four enjoyable (but modest) murder mysteries: BULLDOG DRUMMOND ESCAPES, BULLDOG DRUMMOND'S PERIL, BULLDOG DRUMMOND COMES BACK, and BRITISH INTELLIGENCE. For me, the main attraction is in viewing the Bulldog Drummond B-features. Having said that, BRITISH INTELLIGENCE, which stars Boris Karloff, happens to be a solid espionage thriller.- BULLDOG DRUMMOND ESCAPES (1937, 67 minutes)Note that this story is based on the play BULLDOG DRUMMOND AGAIN by British writer/creator H.C. ("Sapper") McNeile and by Gerard Fairlie. It's a testament to Captain Hugh "Bulldog" Drummond's adventurous life that no sooner does he fly into London than the Commissioner of Scotland Yard is imploring him to leave England. It's too late, of course, as Captain Drummond is already steeped in a mystery involving a lovely damsel in distress. A dashing gentleman simply can't back out. Not the Saint. Not the Falcon. And certainly not Bulldog Drummond.But is the lovely heiress, Phyllis Clavering (Heather Angel), suffering from a persecution complex or is she truly being held in her own manor against her will? Captain Drummond doesn't doubt that something nefarious is going down, and that the oily so-called friend of the family (Porter Hall) is at the bottom of things. Drummond is aided by his delightfully deadpan butler Tenny (E.E. Clive) and his bumbling but loyal pal Algy Langworth (Reginald Denny) whose pregnant wife is in the delivery room (rendering Algy quite a bit distracted). Ray Milland makes for a lively amateur sleuth in his only time playing Bulldog Drummond. This film features lots of cat and mouse games, and slipping thru doors, a secret passage, and both of Drummond's assistants eventually ending up with matching black eyes. Heather Angel makes for a plucky Ms. Clavering. It seems like she's conking someone over the head with a blunt instrument every other scene, that's how plucky she is. She even (accidentally) cracks Drummond on the skull during a life-and-death struggle. From such actions can love spring forth. Heather Angel is really cute.- BULLDOG DRUMMOND COMES BACK (1937, 57 minutes)Based on McNeile's THE FEMALE OF THE SPECIES, this film marks John Howard's suave debut as Bulldog Drummond, former Captain of His Majesty's Royal Air Force, a role he would reprise six more times. The film opens with a smitten Drummond penning a feeble poem and contemplating wedding bells with his lady love, Phyllis Clavering (this time played by Louise Campbell who doesn't have Heather Angel's presence or striking looks). But plans of a marital nature are torpedoed when Phyllis is abducted (again) and by a pair of vengeance-minded continental villains. Drummond and his sidekicks and Colonel Nielson (John Barrymore) negotiate a trail of cryptic clues left like bread crumbs by the kidnappers. But, surely, this can't be a deadly trap? Hell, maybe the whole thing was orchestrated by Phyllis herself. That poem was pretty weak.BULLDOG DRUMMOND COMES BACK is a neat little thriller made more entertaining by Barrymore's outlandish disguises. As usual, there's a peppering of fairly amusing dialogue, with the butler Tenny (E.E. Clive) - frequently the clearest thinker of the bunch - this time thick in the action and Algy Langworth again the preoccupied friend (this time Algy is dithering about his baby's christening). John Barrymore, by the way, even though not the lead, nevertheless gets top billing... because he's John Friggin' Barrymore! When Drummond is about to lay a rough smacking on the disguised Colonel Nielson, Nielson exclaims: "You - you surely wouldn't impair a profile that had endured this long, would you?" And if you know a bit of Barrymore's history, that's a cheeky wink to his famous nickname.- BULLDOG DRUMMOND'S PERIL (1938, 66 minutes)Based on H.C. McNeile's THE THIRD ROUND, it's John Howard's third time as Bulldog Drummond. And maybe marriage just isn't in the cards for Drummond and Phyllis Clavering (Louise Campbell). And, in fact, "Bulldog and Phyllis just almost getting married but then Bulldog gets distracted" is a plot thread that became a running joke throughout this series. Here, they're on the verge of tying the knot again, this time in Geneva, Switzerland, until Bulldog gets drawn into a case involving artificially-manufactured diamonds and a series of gruesome murders. Never mind that he'd promised his fiancee that his wild adventuring days are behind him.The introduction of the "unnatural" diamond adds an element of the fantastic to the plot. And there's good tension in the cat and mouse games played out by Drummond and the clever and unflappable head of a metropolitan diamond syndicate. You can see why this gent isn't too keen on making public the news regarding a synthetic diamond (of which creative process its scientist creator intends to share with the world). Barrymore is back as Scotland Yard's Colonel Nielson and, this time, he plays the scoffing and obstructive presence to Drummond's investigation.And there's also a penguin running amok. E.E. Clive, Reginald Denny (never more a dim bulb), and Louise Campbell also return to round out the familiar cast. BULLDOG DRUMMOND'S PERIL is another fast-paced yarn, and it culminates in a pretty terrific showdown of sword versus bullwhip between Bulldog and one of the villains. Note that the picture quality isn't all that; it looks rather washed out, really. That may be the only negative thing I can think of about this film.- BRITISH INTELLIGENCE (1940, 61 minutes)Whaaaaat?!! Boris Karloff, in a sinister role? The man is seriously in jeopardy of being typecast. Here he is in BRITISH INTELLIGENCE, with yet another menacing turn. But as is his wont, there's a depth to the performance - or maybe it's just a certain panache - and you have to appreciate the character-building details he injects so studiously. Karloff stars in a tense wartime thriller which tracks two German operatives who have infiltrated an English cabinet minister's household. Meanwhile, the British Intelligence department has got its panties in a bunch, stymied time and again in its attempts to nab one of Germany's most elusive masters of espionage. Loose lips are sinking ships like a mother.Karloff assumes a nasty facial scar and a clubfoot in his role of Valder, a loyal French manservant who, we immediately assume (because it's Karloff playing him), isn't so loyal. Margaret Lindsay plays sometime nurse, sometime German spy Helene von Lorbeer who gets an invite to that same household. And I think I'll stop almost right there. I'll further mention that, in this serpentine spy picture, allegiances are fluid, with the agents flipping sides so frequently that you'll get whiplash. Predictably, these key participants don't cement their positions until the third act, as one enemy agent finalizes a plan to murder the entire British cabinet. This is a short and fun movie to watch, with a top notch Karloff demonstrating yet again why he's so good at playing three-dimensional monsters. But do bring a scorecard. It's hard to keep up, with so many wolves in the fold trying on so many hats.
